speaker: Facebook posts
vclaim: Now Facebook says he's got a magic checker.
date: stated on October 7, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: Federal fliers on a "magic checker " on Facebook are just a bunch of pocus.
text: Who doesn't like to challenge good Facebook? And during the Halloween season, what's better than having an algorithm that determines which of us are secret witches? This is what many users claim is currently doing on the social media platform. Facebook, like this, claims that after writing "#HocusPocus" in a comment, one of two things will happen: words will remain the same, revealing that you're a joke or Facebook will turn it into a green tape with the word "magic." Some articles even show comments with purple bars that say "head witch" or "very big witch." We're talking about a big promotion to the witch community. These articles were referred to as part of Facebook's efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) If you try it and nothing happens, don't worry because it's not real. You can still receive your Hogwarts message. On January 10, 2021, in an article on Facebook that says that Nancy Belusi sent a letter to the mayor of Portland after demonstrations there "requiring him to stick to a proven democratic playbook." By Sierra Orrick • January 11, 2021, she will notice that most of the comments on these articles still say "Hocuspocus," because users are honestly writing it to see if it will change. The few that appear to be "witches" or other addresses have been copied and glued to comments. These types of articles were initially created to collect comments and participate, thereby increasing participation on the Facebook page. The fact-finding site TreatorFiction.com found the claim of "magic examiner" to be like another challenge - #911snitch. These articles claimed that writing 911 Sinch revealed whether commentators were "assholes" if words remained the same whether a green cigar bar appeared impolitely and not a rat. The site, like #HocusPocus, wrote #911snitch, "Never produced a green tape to prove that you or your friends aren't rats." The Facebook spokesman for Bolivi Fuckett also stated that there is no "magic checker" advantage. The Internet, again, put a spell on us. We're assessing this allegation pants on fire!
